docs.lead_paragraph: Health costs will grow faster than the government now assumes, partly because of advances in medical technology, and the long-term financial outlook for Medicare is therefore less rosy than officials assume, a federal advisory panel has concluded. The chairman of the panel, composed of three economists and three actuaries, presented its findings today to Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services. It is the first such outside review in nearly a decade. Dr. Shalala is one of six Medicare trustees.
docs.abstract: Techincal Review Panel on the Medicare Trustees' Reports, federal advisory panel created by health and human services secretary Donna Shalala, concludes that health costs will grow faster than government now assumes, partly because of advances in medical technology, and that long-term outlook for Medicare is less rosy than officials assume; panel chairman Dale H Yamamoto and other members comment on findings; study's conclusions discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cerulean Companies, the parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia, said last night that it had agreed to be acquired by WellPoint Health Networks Inc. for $700 million in cash as WellPoint countered an unsolicited $675 million cash offer from Trigon Healthcare Inc. WellPoint and Cerulean originally agreed to merge in July 1998. Under that agreement, WellPoint was to buy Cerulean for $500 million in stock and cash.

headline.main: Cerulean to Be Bought by WellPoint Health

docs.abstract: Cerulean Companies, parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia, agrees to be acquired by WellPoint Health Networks for $700 million; rejects Trigon Healthcare bid of $675 million (S)
docs.snippet: The Cerulean Companies, the parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia, said last night that it had agreed to be acquired by WellPoint Health Networks Inc. for $700 million in cash as WellPoint countered an unsolicited $675 million cash offer...

docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the things that New York hospitals have been up to in the last decade -- research, mergers and fights with managed-care companies -- erecting new buildings has not been among them. The trend has been to pull back on space for inpatient care. Hospitals can ill afford to build new buildings because so much care now takes place outside them. Since 1980, 178 hospitals in the state have either closed, merged or been converted to other uses.

headline.main: Economics Driving an Expansion Of Hospitals Catering to Children

docs.abstract: New York hospitals devoted to care of children have expanded over past decade, even though general trend in health care industry has been to pull back on space for inpatient care; such centers have much easier time attracting philanthropic money than adult centers; in addition, Congress has allocated money to cover some costs of training doctors in children's hospitals, and for federal program to insure needy children; construction of major children's hospitals by three hospitals in New York City region discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is 1987 and Stashu Kybartas has his video camera trained on Danny Sbrochi. Danny's once handsome face is covered with lesions from Kaposi's sarcoma, an AIDS-related cancer, and swollen from chemotherapy. Danny revels in the good times -- lying on the beach sunbathing, then cruising for dates, even shooting cocaine and sharing the same needle with five friends -- though the result was AIDS. At a time when gay men like Danny were often portrayed as immoral hedonists who were paying the price for their promiscuity and when people with AIDS were shown on network television with their faces in shadow because of shame and fear, AIDS activists like Mr. Kybartas were busy documenting the epidemic from another perspective.

headline.main: Guggenheim to Show Video Series on Early Days of AIDS

docs.abstract: Guggenheim Museum launches program of screenings at videos documenting AIDS epidemic back in 1980's; videotapes, largely work of AIDS activists, were originally made to fill a perceived gap in news media's coverage of epidemic; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The union representing 4,000 workers at commercial laundries serving New York City's hotels, restaurants and hospitals reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday that provides raises of about 20 percent over three years. But management's chief negotiator said the laundries' labor costs would climb by at least 30 percent, because the deal included substantial improvements in health and pension benefits.

headline.main: Tentative Pact Would Raise Pay Of Laundry Workers About 20%

docs.abstract: Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, which represents 4,000 workers at commercial laundries serving New York City hotels, restaurants and hospitals, reaches tentative contract that provides raises of 20 percent over three years and improvements in health and pension benefits (M)
